edu.sdsmt.thompsonsamson.weatherapp.view

Class FragmentForecast

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.app.Fragment
      • edu.sdsmt.thompsonsamson.weatherapp.view.FragmentForecast
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.content.ComponentCallbacks2, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener

    public class FragmentForecast
extends android.app.Fragment
    Class for displaying the forecast and forecast location. Api calls to model objects are also handled here with an inner class called HandleAPICallListener. Fragment lifecycle operations with the bundle are also handled here.
    Author:
    Andrew Thompson, Scott Samson

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description

      Handles calls back from the asynctasks.

    • Method Detail

      • checkForecastTimestamp

        private boolean checkForecastTimestamp()
        This method checks the current system timestamp and the forecast timestamp to see if a new forecast should be generated. Android system time is in utc so need the timezone offseet before comparing. If the current time in milliseconds minus the timezone offset is greater than the timestamp in milliseconds send by weatherbug's api, then a true is returned and a new forecast should be fetched.
        Returns:
        true if new forecast needed, false if forecast not needed
        See Also:
        onResume()

      • configureTextFields

        private void configureTextFields(android.view.View v)
        Sets up the textViews for the view. This hides the view while loading data and sets up the objects. We wanted to hide any ui objects until the data was loaded to prevent the pending text from displaying. We think it looked a little more clean.
        Parameters:
        v - The view to display the objects in

      • formatDateTime

        private java.lang.String formatDateTime(java.lang.String timestamp)
        Takes a string with the number of seconds in epoch time and returns a string with the time in a date/time format based on the the timestamp parameter.
        Parameters:
        timestamp - number of seconds since 1/1/1970
        Returns:
        The current time as a string in a date/time format
        See Also:
        populateForecast()

      • networkOnline

        private boolean networkOnline()
        Returns true or false based on the device's network connectivity. Sets up the textViews for the view. This hides the view while loading data and sets up the objects. Called from onCreateView method.
        Returns:
        true return true if network connected
        See Also:
        onCreateView(LayoutInflater, ViewGroup, Bundle)

      • onActivityCreated

        public void onActivityCreated(android.os.Bundle savedInstanceStateBundle)
        Creates the activity and checks if the forecast and location exist in the bundle as a parcelable object. If they do, set the members to the bundle data and populate the ui items.
        Overrides:
        onActivityCreated in class android.app.Fragment
        Parameters:
        savedInstanceStateBundle - bundle to load data from

      • onCreate

        public void onCreate(android.os.Bundle argumentsBundle)
        Handles the onCreate event for the fragment. This initializes the location and forecast model objects. If the bundle is not null, the ZipCode is loaded from it. Although, it shouldn't ever be null since we are passing the bundle item to the fragment from the main activity. Just handling it to be safe.
        Overrides:
        onCreate in class android.app.Fragment
        Parameters:
        argumentsBundle - Bundle data passed from main activity to fragment

      • onCreateView

        public android.view.View onCreateView(android.view.LayoutInflater inflater,
                             android.view.ViewGroup container,
                             android.os.Bundle savedInstanceState)
        Creates the view and sets up the layout. The view is inflated to the host activity and ui objects are initialized. This method also checks if the device has a network enabled or will display a toast message.
        Overrides:
        onCreateView in class android.app.Fragment
        Parameters:
        inflater - inflates fragment according to the layout specified
        container - container for a group of views
        savedInstanceState - bundle of data from previous instances
        Returns:
        the fragment forecast returned as a view object to the host activity

      • onDestroy

        public void onDestroy()
        Handle the fragment onDestroy event. This occurs when the app is closed. Need to cancel any asynctasks that might be running. We do this to prevent any zombie processes.
        Overrides:
        onDestroy in class android.app.Fragment

      • onPause

        public void onPause()
        Handle the fragment onPause event. This occurs when rotating the device. Need to cancel any asynctasks that might be running. We do this to prevent any zombie processes.
        Overrides:
        onPause in class android.app.Fragment

      • onResume

        public void onResume()
        Handle the fragment onResume event. This occurs right after creating the view and whenever the device is rotated. This is where we decided to do the api web calls to ensure the newest data is loaded. If the location is null, the asynctask will be executed to get that data. If the forecast time is null or the system time is greater than the forecast time, a new asynctask will be executed for the forecast.
        Overrides:
        onResume in class android.app.Fragment

      • onSaveInstanceState

        public void onSaveInstanceState(android.os.Bundle savedInstanceStateBundle)
        Saves the current forecast and forecast location data to the bundle.
        Overrides:
        onSaveInstanceState in class android.app.Fragment
        Parameters:
        savedInstanceStateBundle -

      • populateForecast

        private void populateForecast()
        Helper function to set the forecast and display it. Used in a couple areas, so used it as a seperate method.
        See Also:
        FragmentForecast.HandleWebCallListener.onForecastLoaded(Forecast), onActivityCreated(Bundle)

      • populateLocation

        private void populateLocation()
        Helper function to set the location. Used in a couple areas, so easier to set it here
        See Also:
        FragmentForecast.HandleWebCallListener.onLocationLoaded(ForecastLocation), onActivityCreated(Bundle)

      • stopTasks

        private void stopTasks()
        Stops any currently running asynctasks. We do this when the view is paused or destroyed to prevent zombie processes. The tasks are generally short run anyways, but this at least keeps them cleaned up.
        See Also:
        onPause(), onDestroy()
